{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3179113,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-02T20:41:35.856Z","cooked":"

Question for software gurus:
Would a 2nd CAN bus based around the Microchip MCP2515 SPI CAN controller be something “easy” to manage by the RIO? I think we could easily design and make a PCB that has the controller, a CAN transceiver, and connectors for the RIO SPI port + CAN bus. But software support isn’t my forte so I don’t know if it’s worth the effort to do so. If it is possible it would be a cheaper, more universal way to get a 2nd CAN bus vs the CANivore.

Is this to operate with custom devices or to try to work with existing motor controllers? It would get significantly harder for the latter.

There’s also potential issue with R718

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-02T23:05:20.366Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":126,"readers_count":125,"score":30.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":432731,"topic_slug":"spi-to-can-controller-for-2nd-can-bus-idea","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/spi-to-can-controller-for-2nd-can-bus-idea/432731/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3179216,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-02T23:12:32.023Z","cooked":"

If the software support is ever enabled, a standard USB CAN device (such as a SPARK MAX or Copperforge VulCAN) may be easier to implement and would be even more accessible to teams.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-02T23:12:32.023Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":48.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":432731,"topic_slug":"spi-to-can-controller-for-2nd-can-bus-idea","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://shop.copperforge.cc/products/ac41?variant=32438044917859","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"VulCAN USB->CANbus Adapter - Copperforge – Copperforge, LLC","clicks":19}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/spi-to-can-controller-for-2nd-can-bus-idea/432731/3","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3179285,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-03T00:40:57.701Z","cooked":"

I was thinking existing motor controllers. The MCP2515 has been around awhile and its interface is well documented for Arduino projects.
I hesitate to use USB because it necessarily involves custom firmware in an external microcontroller. Since the MCP2515 doesn’t have firmware - it’s a fixed function device - I thought it would be easier to prove as safe, and its driver could be something implemented in the low level RIO code in a similar fashion to the existing CAN stack.
I have no real idea how to do that sadly, I’m a hardware guy.
R718 is sadly a showstopper without the support of FIRST. It’s kind of a chicken and egg issue - somehow the CANivore got certified, and this device would have to go through the same procedure, but with most of the work done in the RIO driver.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-04-03T00:40:57.701Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":100,"readers_count":99,"score":45.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":432731,"topic_slug":"spi-to-can-controller-for-2nd-can-bus-idea","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/spi-to-can-controller-for-2nd-can-bus-idea/432731/4","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3179305,"name":"Thad House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-03T01:23:31.308Z","cooked":"

Technically the USB devices are even easier. Drivers already exist in the Linux kernel for gs-usb, theyre just not compiled in. If that were enabled, they would just automatically work as CAN does in normal linux. Theoretically the same thing could even happen for the MCP2515. It has a linux kernel driver as well, that just isn’t enabled. In both cases, they show up as socketcan interfaces.

Theoretically, I don’t see the rules actually being a big blocker here. Instead, it would be getting vendors to update all their devices to work over a completely separate CAN interface. That kind of abstraction can (ha) be difficult, as the APIs for socketcan are completely different from the netcomm can apis currently used.

beedward:

R718 is sadly a showstopper without the support of FIRST. It’s kind of a chicken and egg issue - somehow the CANivore got certified, and this device would have to go through the same procedure, but with most of the work done in the RIO driver.

My take on this is that I don’t see the current wording of R718 as prohibiting other CAN adapters. R718 reads:

Additional CAN bus connections may be added to the roboRIO using the CTR Electronics CANivoreTM P/N 21-678682 USB-to-CAN adapter.

The key part of this being that it says “may be” instead of “may only be” or “must be”. As it stands, it doesn’t seem that the CANivore is the only allowed way to add additional an CAN bus, although it’s currently the only easily accessible option.
